steps.title: Get Out of Sun
steps.description: Move to shade or indoors immediately. Remove any clothing that might be irritating the burned skin.

steps.title: Cool the Skin
steps.description: Take cool (not cold) baths or showers. Apply cool, wet towels to the burned areas for 15-20 minutes several times a day.

steps.title: Hydrate Inside and Out
steps.description: Drink lots of water to prevent dehydration. Apply moisturizer with aloe vera while skin is still damp. Avoid products with alcohol.

steps.title: Protect Blisters
steps.description: Don't pop blisters - they protect healing skin underneath. If blisters break, clean gently and apply antibiotic ointment.

steps.title: Seek Medical Care
steps.description: Get immediate medical attention for severe burns with extensive blistering, fever, chills, or signs of infection like pus or red streaking.

steps.title: Don't Move the Person
steps.description: Keep the person still and calm. Do not try to move them unless they are in immediate danger. Movement can worsen the injury.

steps.title: Control Bleeding
steps.description: If there is bleeding, apply gentle pressure around the wound with a clean cloth. Do not apply pressure directly over the fracture site or protruding bone.

steps.title: Immobilize the Area
steps.description: Support the fractured area above and below the injury. Use a splint (rigid board, magazine, or cardboard) padded with cloth. Secure with bandages or tape, but not too tightly.

steps.title: Apply Ice Carefully
steps.description: Apply ice wrapped in a cloth for 15-20 minutes to reduce swelling and pain. Never apply ice directly to skin or over an open fracture.

steps.title: Monitor and Seek Help
steps.description: Watch for signs of shock (pale, clammy skin, rapid breathing). Keep the person warm and call 911 immediately for transportation to hospital.

steps.title: Apply Ice Immediately
steps.description: Apply ice wrapped in a towel for 15-20 minutes as soon as possible after the injury. This helps reduce swelling and pain.

steps.title: Elevate if Possible
steps.description: If the bruise is on an arm or leg, elevate it above heart level when resting to help reduce swelling.

steps.title: Avoid Heat Initially
steps.description: For the first 24-48 hours, avoid heat, hot baths, or heating pads as these can increase swelling and make bruising worse.

steps.title: Take Pain Relievers
steps.description: Take acetaminophen for pain. Avoid aspirin or ibuprofen initially as they can increase bleeding and make bruising worse.

steps.title: Monitor for Complications
steps.description: Seek medical care if the bruise is very large, extremely painful, or if you develop signs of infection like increased warmth or red streaks.

steps.title: Sit Down Immediately
steps.description: Have the person sit down immediately to prevent falling. If lying down, keep the head slightly elevated with pillows.

steps.title: Stay Still
steps.description: Avoid sudden movements. Keep the head as still as possible until the spinning sensation passes.

steps.title: Fix Your Gaze
steps.description: Focus on a stationary object to help reduce the spinning sensation. Close eyes if this helps reduce symptoms.

steps.title: Hydrate
steps.description: Sip water slowly if able. Dehydration can worsen vertigo symptoms.

steps.title: Seek Medical Care
steps.description: If vertigo is severe, persistent, or accompanied by hearing loss, headache, or neurological symptoms, seek medical attention immediately.

steps.title: Check Responsiveness
steps.description: Tap the person's shoulders firmly and shout 'Are you okay?' If no response, call 911 immediately or have someone else call while you begin CPR.

steps.title: Position the Person
steps.description: Place the person on their back on a firm, flat surface. Tilt their head back slightly by lifting the chin and tilting the forehead.

steps.title: Hand Placement
steps.description: Place the heel of one hand on the center of the chest between the nipples. Place your other hand on top, interlacing your fingers. Keep your arms straight and shoulders directly over your hands.

steps.title: Perform Chest Compressions
steps.description: Push hard and fast, compressing the chest at least 2 inches deep. Allow complete chest recoil between compressions. Compress at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute.

steps.title: Continue Until Help Arrives
steps.description: Perform continuous chest compressions without stopping until emergency medical services arrive or the person regains consciousness. Switch with another person every 2 minutes if possible to avoid fatigue.

input: What to do if someone is Drowning?

steps.title: Ensure Safety
steps.description: Do not enter the water unless you are a trained lifeguard. Instead, throw a flotation device or extend a pole/rope to the person. Call 911 immediately.

steps.title: Remove from Water
steps.description: Once the person is safely out of water, place them on their back on a firm surface. Be careful with head and neck - suspect spinal injury if they dove or fell.

steps.title: Check Breathing
steps.description: Check for breathing by watching the chest rise and fall for 10 seconds. If not breathing normally, begin rescue breathing immediately.

steps.title: Begin CPR if Needed
steps.description: If no pulse and not breathing, begin CPR immediately. For drowning victims, start with 2 rescue breaths before chest compressions.

steps.title: Monitor and Treat
steps.description: Even if the person recovers, they need medical evaluation. Watch for secondary drowning symptoms like coughing, chest pain, or difficulty breathing hours later.

steps.title: Assess the Situation
steps.description: Check if the person can speak or cough. If they can make sounds, encourage them to keep coughing to try to dislodge the object. If they cannot speak or cough, proceed immediately to back blows.

steps.title: Perform Back Blows
steps.description: Stand behind the person and lean them forward. Using the heel of your hand, give 5 sharp blows between the shoulder blades. Check if the object is dislodged after each blow.

steps.title: Give Abdominal Thrusts
steps.description: If back blows don't work, stand behind the person and wrap your arms around their waist. Make a fist and place it just above the navel. Grasp the fist with your other hand and give 5 quick upward thrusts.

steps.title: Alternate Techniques
steps.description: Continue alternating between 5 back blows and 5 abdominal thrusts until the object is expelled or the person becomes unconscious.

steps.title: Call for Help
steps.description: If the person becomes unconscious, call 911 immediately and begin CPR. If alone with a conscious person, call 911 after trying the above techniques for 1 minute.

input: How do you treat a bleeding nose?

steps.title: Sit and Lean Forward
steps.description: Have the person sit upright and lean slightly forward. This prevents blood from flowing back into the throat, which can cause nausea or vomiting.

steps.title: Pinch the Nostrils
steps.description: Using thumb and index finger, pinch the soft part of the nostrils together firmly. Hold for 10-15 minutes without releasing to check.

steps.title: Apply Ice
steps.description: Apply ice wrapped in a thin cloth to the bridge of the nose and cheeks. This helps constrict blood vessels and reduce bleeding.

steps.title: Breathe Through Mouth
steps.description: Have the person breathe through their mouth while maintaining pressure on the nose. Avoid talking, swallowing, or spitting during this time.

steps.title: Check and Seek Help
steps.description: After 15 minutes, gently release pressure. If bleeding continues, repeat for another 15 minutes. If bleeding doesn't stop after 30 minutes, seek medical attention.

steps.title: Check Responsiveness
steps.description: Check if the person is responsive by gently tapping their shoulders and calling their name. Look for normal breathing.

steps.title: Position Properly
steps.description: If breathing normally, place the person on their back and elevate their legs 8-12 inches above the heart to improve blood flow to the brain.

steps.title: Loosen Clothing
steps.description: Loosen any tight clothing around the neck, chest, and waist. Ensure good air circulation around the person.

steps.title: Check for Injuries
steps.description: Look for any injuries that may have occurred during the fall. If you suspect head, neck, or back injury, do not move the person.

steps.title: Monitor and Seek Help
steps.description: If the person doesn't regain consciousness within 1-2 minutes, call 911. When they wake up, have them sit up slowly and rest before standing.

steps.title: Move to Cool Area
steps.description: Immediately move the person to a cool, shaded area or air-conditioned environment. Remove excess clothing and any tight garments.

steps.title: Cool the Body Rapidly
steps.description: Apply cool water to the skin and fan the person. Focus on neck, armpits, and groin areas. Use ice packs wrapped in cloth on these areas if available.

steps.title: Monitor Temperature
steps.description: Check body temperature frequently. Continue cooling until body temperature drops to 102°F (39°C) or below, then stop to prevent overcooling.

steps.title: Give Fluids if Conscious
steps.description: If the person is conscious and able to swallow, give small sips of cool water. Do not give fluids if they are vomiting or unconscious.

steps.title: Seek Emergency Care
steps.description: Call 911 immediately. Heat stroke is life-threatening and requires immediate medical attention even if the person appears to recover.
